Question: 27 years old patient brought to ER after RTA presented with muffled heart sounds, his blood  pressure 90/60 and increased JVP what is the most probably cause of this condition?
A 60 years old patient admitted in your HDU after total colectomy operation, you noticed that  he became Hypoxic after subclavian central venous line insertion, what is the probable Cause?
A 30 years old patient brought to ER with rib fracture patient is intubated, then becomes  hypotensive and hypoxic what is your diagnosis?
A 28 years old patient stabbed on right side posterior to axillary line. x ray showing pneumothorax with fluid level. What is the best management?

A 50-year-old alcoholic man attends the emergency department. His main reason for presenting is that he has no home to go to, On examination he has no evidence of involvement in recent trauma; a skull x-ray fails to show any, evidence of skull fracture. He is admitted and twelve hours following admission he develops sudden onset headache, becomes comatose and then dies.

A 50-year-old lady is admitted having fallen down some stairs sustaining mutiple rib fractures  36 hours previously. On examination she is confused and agitated and has clinical evidence of  lateralizing signs. She deteriorates further and then dies with no response to resuscitation.

A male infant is born at 28 weeks gestation by emergency cesarean section. He is taken to  theatre for a colostomy. Due to an imperforate anus. He initially seems to be progressing well.  However, he begins to develop decerebrate. Posturing and is becoming increasingly obtunded.
A previously fit 21-year-old man collapses while running a Marathon. Resuscitation  unsuccessful a post-mortem examination shows an intracranial hemorrhage. what is Likely site of the hemorrhage?
Patient hit by ball, has depressed skull fracture, no vomiting or loss of consciousness what is the next step should to do?
A man brought to emergency department with head injury initially GCS was 15, after some time GCS deteriorated to 10 what is the possible cause?
A 30 years old patient brought to ER with history of RTA his Echo showing cardiac Tamponade  for which pericardiocentesis was done what is the proper site of insertion?
Option 1: Between Xephoid process and left sternocostal margin
Option 2: Between Xephoid process and right sternocostal margin
Correct Answer: Between Xephoid process and left sternocostal margin

Question: Man presenting with head injury showing deterioration in GCS which becomes 3 with unilateral  unreactive pupil?
Man presenting with head injury showing deterioration in GCS which becomes 11 with his  mean atrial blood pressure 78mmHlg and ICP 18mmHlg calculate Cerebral perfusion pressure?
A baby is brought to casualty unconscious and in a vegetative state. She has cigarette burns on  her legs. What is the most likely underlying injury?
A 50 year old patient came to ER assessment of consciousness level was done according to GCS patient can localizes pain, open eye to pain and sounds what the GCS?
Injury to orbit of eye due to direct hit by a squash ball. Now presents with diplopia. Visual acuity normal. Xray orbit anatomy is normal. Best next investigation?
A27 year old patient admitted at ICU Having a manifestation of increased ICP Which of the following intervention will decrease raised ICP with immediate effect?
Trauma to face affecting orbit with periorbital hematoma and subconjunctival hemorrhage and epistaxis the type of injury?
A 29 year old patient brought to ER after falling from the floor. A patient is non responsive to any stimuli there is no eye opening what is his GCS?
A young man stabbed in the left 5th ICS, vitally stable apart of tachycardia, normal chest x-ray, what is the next step to do?
In an emergency what is the most appropriate surgical method of obtaining an airway?
Option 1: Cutting and retracting the cricothyroid muscle
Option 4: Entering the trachea at the C7 level

Question: A 25-year-old man is admitted having been stabbed in the interior chest. On examination he is alert and coherent He has congested neck veins His pulse is 140 beats/ minute and his blood pressure 90/60 mmHg. He has normal breath sounds. What is the most likely cause of his cardiac arrest 15 minutes later?

A 19 year-old man fell down a flight of stairs On presentation to the Emergency Department his Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) was 14/15 with no local neurological signs An hour later he Vomited, and his GCS deteriorated to 10. He developed a fixed and dilated left pupil Which of the following is likely to seen on the scan?

23-year-old man is stabbed in the right upper quadrant and is hemodynamically unstable. A laparotomy is performed, and the liver has some extensive superficial lacerations and is bleeding profusely. The patient becomes progressively more hemodynamically unstable. What is the best management option?
Option 1: Pack the liver and close the abdomen with Bogota bag system
Option 2: Occlude the hepatic inflow with a pringles maneuver and suture the defects
Option 3: Occlude vascular inflow and resect the most severely affected area anatomically
Option 5: Suture the defects without vascular occlusion
Correct Answer: Pack the liver and close the abdomen with Bogota bag system

Question: Three days after an isolated head injury from the fall, 76-year-old woman is admitted for drowsiness and confusion. There are no localizing sings. ACT scan is most likely to show.
Option 1: A cerebral hematoma on the right side with cerebral swelling and midline shift to the left
Option 2: A depressed frontal fracture communicating with the frontal sinus and sing of the infection
Option 3: An expanding extradural hematoma on the left side with cerebral swelling
Option 4: Blood in the subarachnoid space and cerebral ventricles with secondary hydrocephalus
Option 5: Cerebral atrophy with subdural collection on the left side
Correct Answer: Cerebral atrophy with subdural collection on the left side

Question: Trauma to face affecting orbit with periorbital hematoma ad subconjunctival hemorrhage and epistasis the fracture site

A 19-year-old man fell down a flight of stairs. On presentation to the Emergency Department his Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) was 14/15 with no local neurological signs. An hour later he Vomited, and his GCS deteriorated to 10.He developed a fixed and dilated left pupil Which of the following accounts for pupillary sings?
Option 1: Compression of oculomotor nerve parasympathetic fibers
Option 2: Compression of sympathetic fibers to the left iris
Option 3: Compression of the afferent fibers of the optic nerve
Correct Answer: Compression of oculomotor nerve parasympathetic fibers

Question: A 70-year-old man with carcinoma of the bronchus presents with blurring of vision, headaches and nausea, particularly in the morning. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
A young man stabbed in the Left Sth ICS, he is vitally stable apart of tachycardia, normal chest x- ray, what is the next step to do?
52 years old fell from stairs, his wife believes he lost consciousness for 15 seconds only, he feels totally recovered now, what to do?
Option 5: Discharge and advise on warning sings
Correct Answer: Discharge and advise on warning sings

Question: 31-year-old lady is struck by a car and is 32 weeks pregnant. On arrival in the emergency department she has a systolic blood pressure of 105mmHg and a pulse rate of 126 beats per minute. Abdominal examination demonstrates a diffusely tender abdomen and some left sided flank bruising. A FAST scan is normal, What is the most appropriate course of action?
Option 1: Arrange a departmental abdominal USS scan
Option 2: Arrange an urgent abdominal MRI scan
Option 5: Arrange an urgent abdominal CT scan
Correct Answer: Arrange an urgent abdominal CT scan

Question: What is the imaging of choice for fracture of the face?
A22 year old patient w history of RTA and his examination showing Raised JVP, trachea shifted to right no breath sounds on left, what to do?
Option 1: A chest drain to anterior left side
Option 2: chest drain to posterior right side

Question: A 19- year-old man fell down a flight of stairs., On presentation to the Emergency Department his Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) was 14/15 with no local neurological signs. An hour later he Vomited, and his GCS deteriorated to 7 what should to do as a next step?
Option 1: Immediate C T brain with in 1 hour

Question: Dissecting thoracic aorta management in patient came in shock but he regains his vitality?
Option 1: IV access and transfer to theatre
Option 2: ECG to detect any rhythm abnormality
Correct Answer: IV access and transfer to theatre

Question: A 25-year-old male pedestrian is hit by a van on a busy road, He is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance. On examination he is dyspnoeic, and hypoxic despite administration of high flow 100% oxygen. His blood pressure is 110/70 and pulse rate is 115 bpm. The right side of his chest is hyper-resonant on percussion and has decreased breath sounds. The trachea is deviated to the left. What is your management?
Option 1: Needle in 5th  intercostal space at the mid axillary line
Option 2: Between Xiphoidal process and left sternocostal margin
Option 3: Between Xiphoidal process and right sternocostal margin
Correct Answer: Needle in 5th  intercostal space at the mid axillary line

Question: A 24-year-old patient presented with trauma to the chest his CR shown widening of the mediastinum. What should to do?

28 year old male is involved in a road traffic accident he is thrown from his motorbike into the pavement and sustains a hemopneumothorax on the right chest. What is the most appropriate course of action?
Option 3: Chest cannula 5th intercostal space mid axillary line
Correct Answer: Chest cannula 5th intercostal space mid axillary line

Question: A 16 year old man sustains a basal skull fracture and is suspected of having CSF rhinorrhoea Which of the following laboratory tests would most accurately identity whether CSF is present or not?
Option 1: Microscopy to identify red blood cells

Question: RTA Patient hits his head ,he has GCS of 15 upon arrival and his GCS of 13 after 2 hours there is a small laceration over his cheek. What is the next step should to do?

RTA patient admitted after observation then discharged by giving treatment. 10 days later came  with abdominal discomfort especially after eating, it became worse. What is the cause?

A 19-year-old student falls from a 2nd floor window. He is hypotensive, though this improves  with a small volume of crystalloid. A CXR shows depression of the left main bronchus and  deviation of the trachea to the right. What is the most likely injury?

Old Patient attended A&E with history of falling in the pavement of a pub. He admits that he was drunk but this never happened before. It's unclear if he lost consciousness or not. He lives alone. He has a small cut by eye otherwise normal on examination. What is your management?
Option 1: Discharge with advice and be accompanied
